html:
• anchor

    A Paper Log House prototype built after the 2023 Maui wildfires. Image courtesy Hawaii Off-Grid Architecture and Engineering

    The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has acquired the Paper Log House designed by Shigeru Ban for its permanent Architecture + Design collection. The move works the first time a work from the celebrated architect’s portfolio has entered a major museum’s holdings.

    As we previously reported, the structure was originally featured in an installation held at The Glass House from April to December 2024. The project was fabricated in New York by students from The Cooper Union in collaboration with Ban’s firm. Ban began experimenting with paper tubes in 1985 and used the material to develop the Paper Log House in response to the 1995 Kobe earthquake.

    Designed as a low-cost, rapidly deployable shelter using locally available materials, the Paper Log House has since been adapted and deployed by Ban’s Voluntary Architects’ Network in humanitarian crises around the world. Ban received the Pritzker Prize in 2014 for his innovative approach, and more recently, the Praemium Imperiale in Architecture in 2024, recognizing his work in both disaster response and permanent structures.

    Separately, Ban’s Blue Ocean Dome will also be repurposed following the close of the 2025 Osaka World Expo. The three-dome installation made of bamboo, carbon fiber reinforced plastic and paper tubes are slated for reuse in a Maldives resort designed by Ban that emphasizes prefabrication, recycled materials, and environmental integration.
